utterances: House Speaker John Boehner gaveled in the session just days after he and his fellow Republicans decided to raise the debt ceiling enough to keep the Treasury meeting its obligations until May 19th.
But as Colorado House Republican Scott Tipton noted, there would be a condition attached to such a short extension of the debt ceiling.
That this House and our counterparts in the United States Senate actually pass a budget for the American people.
If we can't do that, then we, as members of Congress, don't deserve to be paid.
No budget, no pay.
Senate Republicans applauded their House colleague's initiative.
John Cornyn is the Senate's number two Republican.
I want to congratulate the House for directing people's attention to the failure of the Senate under Leader Reid to bring a budget to the floor.
And I think the appropriate sanction is no budget, no pay.
That's just me talking, but I believe that's the - it sends a good message.
Some Democrats say they're fine with having their pay docked if there's no budget, but Iowa Senator Tom Harkin says House Republicans are going too far.
I think that's ridiculous because their premise is that we haven't passed a budget, but we did, as you know, in the budget control act.
We passed, as Senator Conrad can tell you, we are operating under limits right now.
It may not be the, quote, ""budget,"" but it is a budget control act and which we passed.
Democratic Leader Reid emphasized the positive when asked about the House bill raising the debt ceiling which is to be voted on tomorrow.
I'm happy to set us a debt ceiling with not entitlement cuts and dollar for dollar, so that's a big step in the right direction.
The White House issued a statement today saying it will not oppose the short-term raising of the debt ceiling proposed by House Republicans.
But spokesman Jay Carney said the president will not negotiate with Congress over the debt ceiling, either in the short term or the long term.

The president takes some of the statements by Republican leaders and important and prominent Republicans about the absolute folly of pursuing a strategy that ties raising the debt ceiling to demands on spending cuts.
The fact that it is folly, you know, we take heart in that because we believe it's good for the economy to cease that practice.
We're not going to engage in it any more in three months than we were going to engage in it now.
Carney added the president will address deficit reduction separately, as long as it's fair and balanced.
David Welna, NPR News, the Capitol.
More than 10,000 athletes are participating in this year's games and a few will become icons.
Michael Phelps, dubbed the greatest Olympian ever; Usain Bolt, the fastest man in the world; Gabby Douglas, the flying squirrel.

Along with their medals, they get prize money, endorsements, their face on a cereal box, a seat on the late night TV couch, but the reality is most Olympic athletes don't achieve stardom, a superlative title or even a medal.
For the people who spend years dreaming of the Olympics and devoting themselves completely to a sport only to come home empty-handed, where do you go from there?
Well, to give us some insight, I'm joined by two Olympians with that experience.
Derek Brown competed in the 1996 Atlanta games in Team Handball.
He's here in the studio with me.
Derek, welcome to the program.
Thank you.
And rower Kate MacKenzie competed in Athens in 2004 in Pairs Rowing.
She's with us from Ann Arbor, Michigan.
Kate, welcome to you.
Thank you so much.
And, Derek, let's start with you and U.S.
Team Handball.
How'd you do in 1996?
We finished ninth, overall.
We had a record of two and four, which was the best record that we've ever had as a U.S.
delegation in the sport of Team Handball, so we were excited to get two wins.
OK.
And, Kate, how about for you with rowing in 2004?
We were also ninth out of 10, so not as well as the teams have done in the past and we were definitely a little bit disappointed with our performance, but it was what we had on that day, so...
Now that part of the issue we understand, but I want to know do you think we will be right back there again come February 7th?
Yes.
I believe that we will face a crisis of potential homelessness because many of the persons in these hotels are very poor.

They eked out a bare existence in New Orleans and other places along the Gulf Coast before the hurricane came, and they've been unable to replicate that low-income status in the various places they live, such as Los Angeles and in New York and in Houston and Dallas, San Antonio and hotel evacuees spread throughout the country.
Let's bring Beverly into the situation.
You sort of have a double-edged sword issue with regard to this.
On one hand, you are in a situation in which you lost your own home, and at the same time, you're very concerned about the environment before people are brought back into New Orleans, is that right?
That's correct.
For the last almost 11 years, we've been working to try to create a cleaner environment for people who live along the Mississippi River chemical corridor, and that includes the city of New Orleans.
And so Katrina just compounded our existing problems by taking a lot of the poisons that already existed in Superfund sites and brown field sites and sort of spread it around all over the city.
The good news is that the contamination turns out not to be as bad as everyone expected it to be, so the city of New Orleans is not a Superfund site.
It would, however, be considered more, in my opinion, a brown field site in the sense that what's there is not good, but it can be cleaned up.
And that's good news for the citizens.
Well, let me ask...
The bad news is that the federal government doesn't seem to have its act together on when and how it's going to assist us in cleaning up our neighborhoods.
Let's talk about that, John Brittian.
How do you prioritize these issues in ter--one, on one hand, the immediate problem seems to be to find housing on a day-to-day basis for the people who were displaced.
But what about Beverly's argument that it wouldn't be right to bring them into an environment that is not healthy for them?
You're quite correct.

The evacuees, though, have a choice of finding more long-term housing wherever they're living outside the Gulf Coast region or coming back into the Gulf Coast region from Mississippi down into New Orleans and St. Bernard parish and living there.
So you have dual goals of helping people find temporary housing wherever they are and finding housing back in the New Orleans area.
And I share Beverly and her organization's concern about environmental cleanliness.

Beverly, there have been some articles written--in fact, there's one today in The Washington Post talking about a white family and a black family moving back into their respective New Orleans neighborhoods.

As you know, race is a fact of life in describing neighborhoods across America, but in New Orleans in particular right now, is there a new racial reality forming in the neighborhoods that are trying to rebuild?
Oh, there's absolutely a racial reality.

The reality is that white neighborhoods are being repopulated and they are better able to return home because of their economic conditions and the fact that their neighborhoods, for the most part, were not as impacted by Katrina as our neighborhoods were.
New Orleans is a very segregated city and that segregation has absolutely nothing to do with the preference of black people wanting to live in segregated neighborhoods.
It's just that as we move out, integrating neighborhoods, looking for better houses, white people continue to leave and we're not chasing behind them anymore.
So our neighborhoods, for some reason, if they're all black, are considered inferior, which I think is not a good description of where I live or where my city is.

So the racial factor is there and because of that, our center, along with other organizations, have been working together to train people how to clean up their own houses along with the United Steelworkers who have been giving free equipment and classes in the Baton Rouge area.
We're getting ready to start doing it in Houston, Texas, in New Orleans and Atlanta, Georgia, Birmingham and a few other cities.
People will know how to go back into their homes.
And we're moving straight away at dealing with the sediments, on coming up with a clean-up plan for neighborhoods to clean up the sediments that have contamination in them...
That's...
...like mercury and arsenic.
There...
All right, out of time.
I have to cut you off.
I apologize, but our time is just running too low.

John Brittian is the chief counsel and senior deputy with the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law; Beverly Wright, founder and director of the Deep South Center for Environmental Justice at Dillard University in New Orleans.
Also, she is a former member of the Army Corps of Engineers' Environmental Advisory Board.
Thank you both.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
This is NPR News.
Japan's prime minister resigned today as head of the country's ruling party in the wake of a huge loss in the nation's parliamentary elections.
Official results won't be certified until tomorrow but it appears the main opposition party has won a sweeping victory.
Media exit polls show the conservative Liberal Democratic Party, or LDP, took a majority of seats in lower house of Parliament.
And that means the party's leader, Shinzo Abe, is poised to become Japan's prime minister for the second time.
Mm.
So much about gold is a good story.
You want to get inside, you want to cool off, you know.
We want to be out there and perform as long as we can, of course.
The Orioles organizations, they want us out there, you know, as much as we can, but they'll be the first to tell us, you know, on a hot night, be careful out there.
If you need to get in and get a break, you know, do it.
And it's - you do get a chance to run in.
But it's generally a lot hotter down on the field level than it is even on the streets in Baltimore.
It can.
Yes.
I mean, there has been times out there where we've had, you know, thermometers down there.
Some of the ground crew people are out there measuring the temperature on the field.
And sometimes it can be upwards of 10, 15, even sometimes a little bit warmer degrees, warmer than what it is on the outside temperature.
So, yes, sometimes on that field, especially on those Sunday afternoon games, as the day is building and that heat's been building up all out there, it can get pretty hot.
And I have to ask, is there just one bird costume, and how many years has it been used?
Well, no, there is more.
I'm not the only performer of the mascot.
I'm actually the guy that's been there right now.
I've been there the longest of our current group.
I've been there now for six years.
There are a couple of other people that perform as well.
Fortunately, we all have our own costume and we have separate components of it, so we - you know, multiple components, I should say.
So, like, you know, several different of like the body skins, and the gloves.

So, as they get, you know, full of sweat and things like that, you know, we can exchange, you know, exchange them out and put on a fresh dry one as we go in for a break, so we don't have to be wearing the same one out there of the entire time we're there.
Nevertheless, I suspect by the end of the season, it gets pretty rank in there.
